title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text: Note: SQL execution sequence will be :- From(and Join)-> Where-> Group By-> Having-> Select-> Order By-> Limit Key tip: WHERE filters rows, HAVING filters groups.

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
section: Aggregate Functions, GROUP BY & HAVING Clause (Reference)
text:
Aggregate Functions, GROUP BY & HAVING Clause (Reference)








Function
Description
Result if no rows found




COUNT(*)
Counts total rows (includes NULLs)
0


COUNT(col)
Counts non-NULL values
0


SUM(col)
Sum of non-NULL values
NULL


AVG(col)
Average of non-NULL values
NULL


MIN(col)
Smallest non-NULL value
NULL


MAX(col)
Largest non-NULL value
NULL




Note:
All aggregate functions ignore NULL values except COUNT(*).

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
Scalar Function Used with Aggregates








Expression
Description
Result if no rows found




ROUND(AVG(col), 2)
Rounds the average to 2 decimal places
NULL




Note:
ROUND() is not an aggregate function.
It is a scalar (numeric) function applied to an aggregate result.
If the aggregate result is NULL, ROUND(NULL) also returns NULL.

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
GROUP BY Clause
The GROUP BY clause is used to group rows that share the same values and apply aggregate functions to each group.

Example
SELECT department, AVG(salary)
FROM employees
GROUP BY department;


Important Rules

Every column in SELECT must be:

In the GROUP BY clause, or
Used inside an aggregate function

Incorrect SELECT mode, SUM(amount) from payment
Correct SELECT mode, SUM(amount) from payment GROUP BY mode
GROUP BY is evaluated after WHERE
GROUP BY can use multiple columns

GROUP BY department, job_title;

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
HAVING Clause
The HAVING clause is used to filter groups, not individual rows.

Example
SELECT department, AVG(salary)
FROM employees
GROUP BY department
HAVING AVG(salary) > 50000;

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
WHERE vs HAVING (Very Important)



WHERE
HAVING




Filters rows
Filters groups


Used before grouping
Used after grouping


Cannot use aggregates
Can use aggregates




Example
SELECT department, COUNT(*)
FROM employees
WHERE status = 'ACTIVE'
GROUP BY department
HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
Query Execution Order (Logical)

FROM
WHERE
GROUP BY
HAVING
SELECT
ORDER BY

title: SQL Aggregate Functions
text:
Key Exam / Interview Takeaways

WHERE ‚Üí filters rows
GROUP BY ‚Üí creates groups
HAVING ‚Üí filters aggregated results
Aggregates return NULL if no rows exist (except COUNT)
